E NOTE, with a great deal of amazement, the plan offered to

Wthe Johns Hopkins Athletic
Board by the Athletic Board of St.
se measure to settle the question of a

John's College, as a compromi
lacrosse game this year between the two institutions.
In this suggested compromise four universities would be involved,
and their present lacrosse schedule revised to a certain degree. Princeton University, the University of Maryland, St. John's College and the
Johns Hopkins University would be required to make a shift of games
in their present schedules.
By the new plan, St. John's would play Princeton on the date that
Hopkins is now scheduled to meet the Tigers, namely May 1 and Hopkins in turn would be ,required to meet Princeton on May 23, the existing date of the Johns Hopkins-University of Maryland game.
Furthermore our game with the University of Maryland would have
to be put off until June 6th, a date after the closing of both of the
Universities.
The St. John's-Johns Hopkins fracas would cake place on May 2,
the day following the St. John's-Princeton game.
In our estimation, this suggested plan is preposterous and we feel
that it would be a very unwise move for all those concerned to adhere to such a suggestion.
All this controversy and wrangling could have been avoided if the
St. John's College had shown any semblance of cooperation on her
part when the schedules were being made up.
At that time, we offered St. John's these dates, namely the 18th and
25th of April and the 6th of June. In reply, the Crabtown powers that
be, said that the two April dates were not satisfactory purely because
it was too early in the season to play Hopkins and that the 6th of June
was out of the question because they would not be able to put a team
on the field at that date.
In return, they offered to us the 2nd of May as the only date that
they could meet the Jay twelve. In reviewing the existing situation, the
Hopkins authorities held that it would be unfair to both St. John's and
Princeton to accept this date in view of the fact that the Princeton
game had been scheduled many months before on Mriday, May 1st.
We can see no reason why St. John's did not accept one of the dates
in April in the first place; but since both of those dates are no longer
open and since the only possible date for the St. John's-Hopkins game
seems to be the 6th of June, we therefore sincerely hope that an agreement to that effect will will soon be reached by the two institutions.

New York, N. Y.—In 1929-30
more than 10,000 foreign students
were registered in some 450 American institutions of higher learning.

over the preceding year.

E NOTE, with a great deal of amazement, the plan offered to

Wthe Johns Hopkins Athletic
Board by the Athletic Board of St.
se measure to settle the question of a

John's College, as a compromi
lacrosse game this year between the two institutions.
In this suggested compromise four universities would be involved,
and their present lacrosse schedule revised to a certain degree. Princeton University, the University of Maryland, St. John's College and the
Johns Hopkins University would be required to make a shift of games
in their present schedules.
By the new plan, St. John's would play Princeton on the date that
Hopkins is now scheduled to meet the Tigers, namely May 1 and Hopkins in turn would be ,required to meet Princeton on May 23, the existing date of the Johns Hopkins-University of Maryland game.
Furthermore our game with the University of Maryland would have
to be put off until June 6th, a date after the closing of both of the
Universities.
The St. John's-Johns Hopkins fracas would cake place on May 2,
the day following the St. John's-Princeton game.
In our estimation, this suggested plan is preposterous and we feel
that it would be a very unwise move for all those concerned to adhere to such a suggestion.
All this controversy and wrangling could have been avoided if the
St. John's College had shown any semblance of cooperation on her
part when the schedules were being made up.
At that time, we offered St. John's these dates, namely the 18th and
25th of April and the 6th of June. In reply, the Crabtown powers that
be, said that the two April dates were not satisfactory purely because
it was too early in the season to play Hopkins and that the 6th of June
was out of the question because they would not be able to put a team
on the field at that date.
In return, they offered to us the 2nd of May as the only date that
they could meet the Jay twelve. In reviewing the existing situation, the
Hopkins authorities held that it would be unfair to both St. John's and
Princeton to accept this date in view of the fact that the Princeton
game had been scheduled many months before on Mriday, May 1st.
We can see no reason why St. John's did not accept one of the dates
in April in the first place; but since both of those dates are no longer
open and since the only possible date for the St. John's-Hopkins game
seems to be the 6th of June, we therefore sincerely hope that an agreement to that effect will will soon be reached by the two institutions.

New York, N. Y.—In 1929-30
more than 10,000 foreign students
were registered in some 450 American institutions of higher learning.
This is an increase of 10% or more
over the preceding year.
The Chinese and Canadians lead
the list of Foreign students with
1,294 and 1,263 respectively, according to the Committee on Friendly Relations among Foreign Students, and the Japanese with 987,
the Philippinos with 887, the Russians with 538, the Germans with
397, the English with 365, the Mexicans with 315 follow in order.

Discusses Dreams

Advancing the theory that there
inner force in man that manian

fests itself in the dream state,

custom, the Thom cup will be
awarded to the winner of the Extemporaneous public speaking contest to be held early in May in Levering Hall. The cup is offered by
Mrs. H. R. M. Thom, prominent
in Baltimore society, in memory of
Hunt Reynolds Mayo Thom, and is
now on display in the main library.
Tryouts will be held in the public
speaking classes during the next
two weeks, in order to determine
upon the final contestants.
